div1.p: Your letter arrived Monday and I waited until after the N.S.R.P meeting to answer. So glad to hear the Laureate Tout was a pleasure for you. Saw the picture of the bust in the World Herald. That must have been a fine surprise.
I have a couple of items of rather sad news about Bancroft, so will tell them first, and then proceed to the more welcome information about the Study Restoration

First sad news, your friend, Mrs. Florence Ward passed away suddenly on Monday. She died in a department store in Sioux City. Her husband was waiting outside for her, must have been a terrible shock for the poor man. The funeral is today. They waited until today because there were, funerals here on Wednesday and Thursday. Martin has been very busy.

The other item of sad news, is like a death, in a way. It concerns the Old Mill and the Ockander property. Place of pleasant memories for all of us who recall Logan when it was a real River. The heirs to the property are dying one by one. Edna, Pete and Bill are the only ones left. They have three offers to sell the place. Edna is trying frantically to keep them from disposing of the house and Mill. If a farmer buys it, they (the two buildings) will be torn down of course. The place plowed under and only corn to mark the spot. A real pity. The rest of the family laugh at Edna and think she is foolish for wanting to preserve the old home. I wrote to Marvin Kivett (Director of Nebr Stat Hist- orical Society, and he told me they do not have money to restore anything of that kind.

Edna (she is still, Miss Edna Ockander) wonders if you might know of someone or some group that would be interested in restoring the Mill. I promised to write and ask you. And
2
I have done so. If you know of any possible way to do something about this situation, please let me know.

Now to more pleasant things. The Neihardt Study Restoration. That is proceeding in a most satisfactory way. The towns best carpenter, a Mr Henry Leriger has promised to do the work on the house Study and told me he would donate most of his labor. Is'nt that wonderful? First thing to be done--remove that big tree stump that nestles up aginst the back wall. Then the foundation, the roof, a new porch and then paint. By that time we will check the treasury and see what is in the bottom of the sack! Am hoping to hear something from the McDonald Foundation. They wrote me that they make their decision in November. Am keeping my fingers crossed. We have decided to put a red wood retaining strip around the crushed white rock border that will edge both Prayer Garden and flower beds. Red wood because it is both attractive and indestructable. By the way, what town is copying our Garden? Suppose it is their privilege, but I dont like it. Copy Cats.

Their is not much more to add just now about the Study, or Bancroft, for that matter. Everyone on the Committee is in the best of health and send you their best. We are all enthused about getting things moving toward the real job of Restoration. Hope the Nebraska winter does'nt interfere too much.
Best to you, and to Alice, Lynn and Erica
